metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data set of late Jurassic two-mica granites in Guangzhou, South China
metadata.description: The data set includes: lithologic information, chronological data, whole rock major and trace elements and Sr-Nd isotopic data, and in-situ Hf-O isotopic data of zircons from the Maofengshan two-mica granites, diorites and syenite porphyries in the Guangzhou area. The chronological data of rock samples are determined by SIMS of magmatic zircon separated from single mineral. During the testing process, Qinghu standard zircon is used as the monitoring sample to monitor the reliability of the whole analysis and testing process. The main elements were determined by X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) by melting the rock powder into a glass sheet which can be tested on the computer. The analytical accuracy of the standard materials GBW-07111, GBW-123, GSR-1, GSR-2 and GSR-3 was better than 2%. Trace elements were analyzed by Perkin Elmer Elan 6000 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). USGS reference materials (BHVO-2, GSR-1, GSR-2, GSR-3, SARM-4, AGV-2 and W-2a) were determined in the process of analysis and test, which were used as external test standards to correct the element content of unknown samples, and the accuracy of analysis and test was better than 3%. The SR Nd isotopic compositions of rocks were determined by means of acid dissolution of powders, and the obtained solutions were monitored by using NBS987 (87Sr / 86Sr = 0.71025) and shin Etsu JNdi-1 (143Nd / 144Nd = 0.512115) standard materials on the Neptune multi receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (MC-ICP-MS). The in-situ Hf isotope of zircon was measured by laser and MC-ICP-MS. During the test, Mud Tank and GJ-1 standard zircon were used as monitoring samples to monitor the reliability of the whole process. In situ O isotopic data of zircons were obtained by SIMS analysis of magmatic zircons. In the process of testing, the external accuracy of multiple determination results of Penglai standard sample is better than 0.30% (2σ).The obtained data provide evidence for the mechanism and process of Late Mesozoic crustal reworking in South China. The research results are published in the international Journal Mineralogy and Petrology.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in word file. The file name "ZirUPb. DOX" represents zircon U-Pb geochronology data. The file name "ZirHfO. DOX" represents zircon HF-O isotope data. The file name "WRMajTra. DOX" represents the major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock. The file name "WRIso. DOX" represents the whole rock isotopic geochemical data.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method for geochemical analysis use standard reference materials to ensure accuracy?

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used for geochemical analysis of biotite granite samples in South China during the Late Jurassic?
Feature Specification.Answer: secondary ion mass spectrometry, X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer, laser ablation, oxygen isotopes, external accuracy monitored by standard samples

Quantification.Question: How many standard materials are used for calibration in the geochemical data collection method?

Definition.Question: What does '二次离子体质谱（SIMS）测定' entail in the context of geochemical data collection?
Definition.Answer: 二次离子体质谱（SIMS）测定 refers to a method used to determine the age of rock samples by analyzing zircon minerals. This technique involves using secondary ion mass spectrometry to measure isotopic compositions, with Qinghu standard zircon as a reference to ensure the reliability of the analysis process.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods used for determining Sr-Nd isotopic compositions in a dataset compare to those used for zircon in-situ Hf-O isotopic analysis in terms of accuracy and reliability?
Comparison.Answer: The methods for determining Sr-Nd isotopic compositions involve acid dissolution of powdered samples followed by analysis using a multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (MC-ICP-MS), employing standard materials NBS987 and Shin Etsu JNdi-1 for monitoring accuracy. Meanwhile, zircon in-situ Hf isotopic analysis employs laser ablation combined with MC-ICP-MS, with Mud Tank and GJ-1 standard zircons as monitoring samples, ensuring reliability. Zircon in-situ O isotopic data is obtained through secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS), with external precision monitored using Penglai standards. Both methods emphasize precision, with Sr-Nd analysis having an accuracy better than 3% and zircon O isotopic analysis having external precision better than 0.30% (2σ).

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes could lead to variations in the precision of geochemical data collection in biotite granite samples from the Late Jurassic period in South China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variations in the precision of geochemical data collection can be caused by factors such as the calibration and reliability of the instruments used, including XRF for major elements and ICP-MS for trace elements, as well as the accuracy of standard reference materials like GBW-07111 and USGS standards. Additionally, the sample preparation process, such as the melting of rock powders into glass discs, and the quality of zircon separation for isotopic dating, can affect precision. The use of specific standards, like Qinghu standard zircon for SIMS analysis, also plays a critical role in ensuring the reliability of age data, while the choice of external standards for Sr-Nd isotopic measurements influences the consistency of results.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure the accuracy and reliability of geochemical data collected from biotite granite samples in the late Jurassic period in South China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy and reliability of the geochemical data are ensured through several procedures: age data of rock samples are determined using Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (SIMS) with Qinghu standard zircon as a control sample; major elements are measured by X-ray Fluorescence Spectrometer (XRF) with an accuracy better than 2% using standard materials GBW-07111, GBW-123, GSR-1, GSR-2, and GSR-3; trace elements are analyzed using Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) with an accuracy better than 3% by measuring USGS standard materials BHVO-2, GSR-1, GSR-2, GSR-3, SARM-4, AVG-2, and W-2a; Sr-Nd isotopes are measured using Multi-Collector ICP-MS with NBS987 and Shin Etsu JNdi-1 as standard materials; in-situ Hf isotopes are tested using laser ablation coupled with MC-ICP-MS with Mud Tank and GJ-1 standard zircon as control samples; in-situ O isotopes are analyzed using SIMS with Penglai standard material ensuring an external precision better than 0.30% (2σ).
